Those will then come through the Institutional Bank and us as a facilitator and as an intermediary to take them into the capital markets, and that has driven the pricing down between the two markets. Those are pretty close to in balance at the moment. So that means, I would say, that the margin compression that we've seen has stabilized for the moment, though the competitive landscape is likely to stay intense. The Europeans pulling out made the first wave of difference. We saw the Asians come in for a little bit and now we've got a more balanced market again. Thank you.

And on the smaller end, and it's really much the same story as we had the whole of last year and where the volume growth is and where the opportunities are really relying on those sectors that are connected to mining and commodities, engineering. So the faster growing sectors of the economy is where the most opportunity is. Health is another one that's got good opportunity. Some areas in agri have got good opportunity as well.
James?

Hi, Gail. James Freeman from Deutsche Bank. I just wanted to ask about the customer deposit to loan ratio that you've increased quite substantially. What is the target number at which you'll start backing off on deposits? And is it growth at all costs or are you prepared to be the bank that'll actually put some pricing discipline back into the deposit market?

Well, it's definitely not growth at all costs. I really hope that this is sort of part of the point of saying it's a balancing act and we look at all of those aligned whether it's strengths, growth, return, and we seek to manage those in a tight coherent way and that's certainly what we've tried to do over the course of this past six months. So it's definitely not growth at all costs, but it's going for those segments and those customer bases that are perhaps less competitively focused on price and making sure we win our own transactions out of our own customers, all those sorts of things.

We haven't actually externally put out a particular ratio. We'd like to increase it from where it is. And so you can expect to see a steady improvement. But again there could be some leads and lags. There could be some periods where it's – plateaus a little and some periods where it steps up a bit. But in this environment where credit growth is low, where system credit growth is low, this is an environment where we would expect to get more structural shift. So this is an environment where I'm putting the asset on the teams out there and say go and actually make sure you shift this culture to deposits and grow this deposit base because we've got a very sizable customer base across our various brands, let's go and get them.

Bank of Melbourne is a great example. They started out with their business case being more lending focused, in a traditional way of a sort of startup and we said, sorry, wrong, get the deposits. So they've grown their deposits by 16% in six months and are four times market share. So that's the shift that we're trying to bring about, but it will be managed, it will be disciplined.

Yeah. I appreciate that, but I mean it's also an environment where deposits are being ridiculously bid for by all four banks, and I think Richard made that point. Is now the right time to be – I mean, you're saying leads and lags. Is now the right time to be actually focused on increasing it when you're paying 5.8% for a term deposit at the moment versus a lending housing loan at almost 5.9%? I mean, the math on this does not make a lot of sense and you're saying it comes through the margins at the moment. I'm just curious as to what point...

I think it is the right time to focus on it because we're in a scenario of lower credit growth, where system credit growth is lower, where we're going through the cycle of customers de-gearing, deleveraging, more caution, I think it is the right time. Phil, I mean, you may want to talk a bit more about the overall funding task and approach that we're taking here. But it is – it's managed is the best way I can say. We really, as a team, Phil and I, Curt, the whole Group Executive, it is a huge area of every week focus.

Look, you've highlighted an issue for the industry and it's how well you can actually achieve growth and at what margin impact. And I think we're trying to make sure that we manage that trade-off. It's – the trade-off is actually no different from lots of periods in the past, but it is pretty acute. And I think you're seeing in the results how some banks have addressed that trade-off. I think our result is not a bad one in terms of getting that balance right.

In terms of other funding sources, I think one of the things that we have got strength, obviously what we've been doing in the term markets and we have a very large pool of potential in that covered bond market. Now we're not going to go off and issue all of our covered bond capacity on day one and we've been quite I think disciplined about that in the last six months. But that is an opportunity for us to actually raise, what will turn out to be, quite cheap money compared to even term deposits. And so we'll be looking to astutely use that over the coming period as well.

I think we've done a reasonable job as well in the last – when I say the industry has done a reasonable job in the last six months or so of better explaining the dynamic nature of how we fund ourselves and the costs of those various funding elements and that there's not this nexus between a cash rate move and how pricing flows through on the lending side. So I think we've done a reasonable job. We need to do more of that because ultimately the balancing act also includes repricing on the mortgage side and repricing on the business banking side, on the lending side, and that's part of what actually gets you into the balance.
We'll take one question from the phone from Matt Davidson.
Matt, can you hear us?
Yes, I – can you hear me?
Yeah, we can hear you.

Okay, Gail, you've given the deposit performance a big kick today, but I guess if we go back to slide 14 we can say that the at call deposits have fallen by $8 billion, and both yourself and Jason have talked about the need to win that transactional banking side of the business. So I'm just interested if there's any specific reasons you can call out for that performance on at call deposits this period, and whether it does reflect any slippage in the business transactional banking space where I think one of your peers is making a lot of noise about their technology advantage in that space?

Look, we've had a very deliberate focus on growing our TDs and there are regulatory reasons for that. That's about term funding and stability of funding and better matching the profile of our funding with our lending. So – and as you move forward into the new stable funding ratio scenario that we all know is coming and yes, there's lot more detail that we've yet to ascertain with regard to that, but we absolutely know that term funding is more valued. So that's been a deliberate shift, it's more valuable for us. With regard to – on the call, that does include online?
Yeah. This is everything.

That's everything. I mean, online is a very hot and not sticky element or potentially not sticky element. And so we're cautious about online. We certainly want to make sure that we don't actually, that goes to your earlier point James, we don't want to make sure that we're pricing at any cost on online. So we're being much more thoughtful and cautious about the – competing at that really hot end of online. We've been focused on TDs, focused on basic transactional savings side, and as Jason knows and the team knows more to do on that everyday transactional banking piece.

Similarly, in Rob's business, there are – transactional banking piece is a strong component of what we do and our business deposits have been very strong. So that's an area where we're doing well. That's an area where we think we can do better.

So I wouldn't say I'm claiming – your opening remark there was that I'm saying we've done well in deposits. I'm not really. I'm saying we've done an okay job of growing our deposits ahead of system and we've done an okay job of funding our lending growth with deposits, and we're doing an okay job of shifting the culture of our organization more towards deposits. I've been talking about this and the – all of the four years that I've been here. It does take time; culture change like this takes time, and we are getting there steadily but surely, but the level of focus, resource, and attention we have on this has stepped up enormously.
We'll take one...
And just on the online, if we strip that out, would you say you're still holding share on the transactional side or is – would you acknowledge any slippage there?
Phil, do you want help on that?

I think I'd absolutely expect that we've actually grown share in particularly business and institutional transactional. Some of that business at call is actually a switch from at call, some of it's actually out of 11am (1:29:11) as well into term deposits. And so that differential actually kind of exaggerates how much is going on. And when you get a chance to read through the ASX, in the divisional commentary we talk about the switch that's taken place between at call and term deposits.

But I think Gail's last comment around rational pricing, if we think 5.6%, 5.8% term deposits for six months is irrational, what about 6% at call? So that is one where we've absolutely said, look, we'd rather see if we can get some more normality in the yield curve even at these elevated pricing. And so we have definitely been comfortable shying away from some of the most price-sensitive online at call offers.
Thank you.
Okay. With that, look, I might call things to a close. We're right on time. Thank you and good afternoon.
Thank you. Thanks, everyone.
